entry.title: Why Does SAP Use the Shortage Date for Storage Cost Calculation Even After Forward Scheduling?
entry.content:
I‚Äôm working with dynamic lot sizing (lot size DY) in MRP and noticed a behavior I‚Äôm struggling to reconcile with the standard logic.

In my scenario:

  • First shortage: 15 January, 44 pcs
  • Next requirement: 6 April, 50 pcs
  • RLT: 9 April (Purchasing Processing time 4 working days + PDT 63 cal. days + GR processing time 10 work days)
  • Storage cost rate: 10%
  • Ordering Costs: 35$
  • MAP: 34.02$
  • SAP calculates 81 extra storage days (6 Apr ‚Äì 15 Jan)

Because backward scheduling produced a start date in the past, SAP switched to forward scheduling. Now the material is only be available on 24 March.

My question is:

Why does the dynamic lot-sizing formula still use the shortage date (15 January) as the start of storage, instead of the actual earliest availability date (24 March)?

Storage Costs = (81 * 34.02 * 10 * 50)/36500 = 37.74$

From a logistics perspective, storage cannot begin before the material physically exists. But SAP continues to calculate extra storage days as if the product were available on the shortage date, even though the system itself determined that the requirement cannot be met until much later.

Is this the intended behavior of DY, or am I misunderstanding something here?

entry.title: Prompt to automate Design Worksheet tabs of the Compensation module workbooks
entry.content:
Introduction

The "Design worksheet" tab of Compensation workbooks contains the details of every field designed in a Compensation template and usually takes a very significant amount of time (and tedious screen comparison work) for consultants to finalize (it could also be customers wanting to update an existing workbook after they made modifications to their templates since the initial implementation - for example new integration to EC). 

While I remain hopeful that one day we will have a button in Admin Center to instantly generate workbooks for any of our HCM Suite modules, for the time being I created a Prompt for GenAI models to automatically create this Design Worksheet tab.

 

 

Pre-requisite (model file download)

This prompt works hand in hand with this Demo xls file which I built using the same exact layout than the module's official workbooks (partner authorization required for this link) and updated with the most recent settings available as of 2H 2025. I simply added an extra column (A) to simplify the prompt and make the file generate faster. Cells A1 to A37 can be deleted once the file has been generated (select > delete and move to left).

 

Screenshot of the Demo file to help GenAI models generate the output:

 

 

Prompt

 

Can you please turn the document attached into a similar workbook than the xls demo example I am attaching. Keep the first two columns A and B the same and start in column C. Important: in the Section Header row use the color code as background color for the merged cells and add the column-id of the column displayed when collapsed (if collapsed instead of expanded). Important: in the Field Name row use the same color for each column as the section header color. Columns with value "Standard-manually entered on form" should be the only ones that have two subcolumns, one for the amount, another for the percentage.

When column A = isCustomField :

  • isCustomField="false" and comp-ect-input-field-map tag missing and readOnly="true" --> "Standard-compensation field".
  • isCustomField="false" and comp-ect-input-field-map tag present --> "Standard-imported from EC or upload".
  • isCustomField="false" and readOnly="false" --> "Standard-manually entered on form".
  • isCustomField="true" and  comp-custom-field-formula tag is present --> "Custom-formula".
  • isCustomField="true" and readOnly="false" --> "Custom-manually entered on form".
  • isCustomField="true" and comp-ect-input-field-map tag present --> "Custom-imported from EC or upload".

When column A = readOnly: true --> Yes, false --> No.

When column A = type: values should be String, Money, Amount, Percent, Date or UserName.

When column A = comp-help-text: if no tag present set to "No" otherwise "Yes".

When column A = comp-help-text-message: leave blank if above line is "No", otherwise copy comp-help-text-message in the cell.

When column A = alignment: fill blank values with "default".

When column A= comp-custom-validation: enter "No" if tag is missing all together, enter "Yes" if present.

Fully remove the following columns: salaryTab, executiveRuleViolation, salaryAction, executiveAction, salaryNote, budgetPlannedTotal, moreToAllocate, budget, mgrFirstName, mgrLastName, userName.

 

 

 

Conclusion

SAP employees must use GenAI tools available through the Generative AI Lab page (lots of famous LLM models are available there) which link can be found through the SAP sharepoint site "CPIT Enterprise AI CoE" (205734) > Big Data and AI Platform > Generative AI Experience Lab.

  • Please note:
    • Some models cannot create a file based on prompts + demo file and will only be able to build Python code that will then need to be imported into a Python software to create the excel.
    • FBP groups permissions do not carry over in exported files hence cannot be automated.
    • As per introduction: Cells A1 to A37 can be deleted once the file has been generated (select > delete and move to left).

 

 

 

Best,

Xavier

 

 


(If you found this blog useful please consider giving it a Kudo)

entry.title: SAC: How to call Content Network job via API using ABAP
entry.content:
The post is a response to the lack of standard mechanisms for performing backups in SAP SAC at the model level by the user.
The inspiration was one of the scenarios considered by Max_Gander in the post:
Options to Back-up Your SAP Analytics Cloud Planni... - SAP Community

In my organization, I used the scenario Back-up model in SAP Analytics Cloud for one of the models. The reason was the longer time needed to develop an ABAP program that could call an import package in Content Network from my favorite SAP BW/4.

Below I will present the code and configuration that will allow you to call the import job in content management without using third-party tools like postman etc.

So it‚Äôs an implementation of Content Network backup scenario from the blog mentioned

1. Set Up Third-Party Access with OAuth Clients

This is the first step, which is best done according to the documentation.
Set Up Third-Party Access with OAuth Clients | SAP Help Portal

Briefly, SAC -> System->Administration->App Integration-> +Add an OAuth Client

When creating an OAuth client, the system displays the secret key only once, so don't forget to copy it

2. Set up connection in SAP BW/4

SM59 -> HTTP Connection to External Server

 

Test it

 

3. Program with all important comments

REPORT REPSACAPI.

DATA: LO_HTTP_CLIENT TYPE REF TO IF_HTTP_CLIENT,
      lo_API02 TYPE REF TO IF_HTTP_CLIENT,
      lo_API02a TYPE REF TO IF_HTTP_CLIENT.
DATA: response TYPE string,
      http_status type string,
      lv_code type i,
      reason type string.
data: lv_url type string.

TYPES: BEGIN OF ty_token_response,
         access_token TYPE string,
         token_type   TYPE string,
         expires_in   TYPE i,
         scope        TYPE string,
         jti          TYPE string,
       END OF ty_token_response.

DATA: ls_token_data    TYPE ty_token_response,
      lv_token         TYPE string,
      lv_atok          type string,
      lv_csrf_token    TYPE string,
      lv_body          TYPE string.


DATA: lt_headers TYPE tihttpnvp,
      ls_header  TYPE ihttpnvp,
      lt_headers01 type tihttpnvp.
DATA: lv_content_length TYPE string.

DATA: lt_cookies TYPE TABLE OF string,
      lv_cookie TYPE string,
      lv_cookie_remaining TYPE string.
DATA  lv_decoded_cookie TYPE string.


*Put your SAC hosi into lv_url_d
PARAMETERS: lv_url_d type string OBLIGATORY LOWER CASE.

******Begin:  to get <Access_Token> *****
CL_HTTP_CLIENT=>CREATE_BY_DESTINATION(
    EXPORTING
        DESTINATION = 'Your RFC name' "Name of the RFC destination
    IMPORTING
        CLIENT = LO_HTTP_CLIENT " HTTP Client object
    EXCEPTIONS
         ARGUMENT_NOT_FOUND = 1
         DESTINATION_NOT_FOUND = 2
         DESTINATION_NO_AUTHORITY = 3
         PLUGIN_NOT_ACTIVE = 4
         INTERNAL_ERROR = 5
         OTHERS = 6 ).

lo_http_client->request->set_method( if_http_request=>CO_REQUEST_METHOD_POST ).
CALL METHOD lo_http_client->send
  EXCEPTIONS
    http_communication_failure = 1
    http_invalid_state         = 2
    http_processing_failed     = 3
    http_invalid_timeout       = 4
    OTHERS                     = 5.
IF sy-subrc = 0.
  CALL METHOD lo_http_client->receive
    EXCEPTIONS
      http_communication_failure = 1
      http_invalid_state         = 2
      http_processing_failed     = 3
      OTHERS                     = 5.
ENDIF.
response = lo_http_client->response->get_cdata( ).
CALL METHOD /ui2/cl_json=>deserialize
  EXPORTING
    json = response
  CHANGING
    data = ls_token_data.
******End:  to get <Access_Token> *****

******Begin:  to get X-CSRF token *****
lv_url = LV_URL_D && '/api/v1/csrf'.
CALL METHOD cl_http_client=>create_by_url
  EXPORTING
 url = lv_url
  IMPORTING
    client             = lo_API02
  EXCEPTIONS
    argument_not_found = 1
    plugin_not_active  = 2
    internal_error     = 3
    OTHERS             = 4.

lo_API02->request->set_method('GET').

lv_atok  = |Bearer { ls_token_data-access_token }|.
lo_API02->request->set_header_field( name = 'Authorization' value = lv_atok ).
lo_API02->request->set_header_field( name = 'x-csrf-token' value = 'fetch' ).
lo_API02->request->set_header_field( name = 'x-sap-sac-custom-auth' value = 'true' ).
lo_API02->request->set_header_field( name = 'DataServiceVersion' value = '2.0' ).
lo_API02->request->set_header_field( name = 'Accept' value = 'application/json' ).

CALL METHOD lo_API02->send
  EXCEPTIONS
    http_communication_failure = 1
    http_invalid_state         = 2
    http_processing_failed     = 3
    http_invalid_timeout       = 4
    OTHERS                     = 5.
IF sy-subrc = 0.
  CALL METHOD lo_API02->receive
    EXCEPTIONS
      http_communication_failure = 1
      http_invalid_state         = 2
      http_processing_failed     = 3
      OTHERS                     = 5.
ENDIF.

call method lo_API02->response->get_status
 IMPORTING
    code = lv_code
    REASON = reason.
CALL METHOD lo_API02->response->get_header_field
  EXPORTING
    name  = 'x-csrf-token'
  RECEIVING
    value = lv_csrf_token.
CALL METHOD lo_api02->response->get_header_fields
  CHANGING
    fields = lt_headers.
response = lo_API02->response->get_cdata( ).
******End:  to get X-CSRF token *****


******Begin: run the job
lv_url = LV_URL_D && '/api/v1/content/jobs'.
CALL METHOD cl_http_client=>create_by_url
  EXPORTING
 url = lv_url
  IMPORTING
    client             = lo_API02a
  EXCEPTIONS
    argument_not_found = 1
    plugin_not_active  = 2
    internal_error     = 3
    OTHERS             = 4.
lo_API02a->request->set_method('POST').

* !!! Crucial: pass cookies
LOOP AT lt_headers INTO ls_header.
  IF ls_header-name = 'set-cookie'.
    IF ls_header-value CS 'JSESSIONID='.
      SPLIT ls_header-value AT ';' INTO lv_cookie lv_cookie_remaining.
      lv_cookie = lv_cookie+11.
      EXIT.
    ENDIF.
  ENDIF.
ENDLOOP.

lv_decoded_cookie = cl_http_utility=>unescape_url(
                escaped   = lv_cookie ).

lv_body = '{"type": "IMPORT", "packageName": "Your Package name","privatePackage": Your Package ID,"allObjects": true}'.

lo_API02a->request->set_header_field( name = 'Authorization' value = lv_atok ).
lo_API02a->request->set_header_field( name = 'x-sap-sac-custom-auth' value = 'true' ).
lo_API02a->request->set_header_field( name = 'Connection' value = 'keep-alive' ).
lo_API02a->request->set_header_field( name = 'Content-Type' value = 'application/json' ).
lo_API02a->request->set_header_field( name = 'x-csrf-token' value = lv_csrf_token ).
lo_API02a->request->set_cookie( name = 'JSESSIONID' value = lv_decoded_cookie ).
lo_API02a->request->set_header_field( name = 'X-Requested-With' value = 'XMLHttpRequest' ).

lv_content_length = strlen( lv_body ).
lo_API02a->request->set_header_field( name = 'Content-Length' value = lv_content_length ).
lo_API02a->request->set_cdata( lv_body ).

CALL METHOD lo_API02a->send
  EXCEPTIONS
    http_communication_failure = 1
    http_invalid_state         = 2
    http_processing_failed     = 3
    http_invalid_timeout       = 4
    OTHERS                     = 5.

IF sy-subrc = 0.
  CALL METHOD lo_API02a->receive
    EXCEPTIONS
      http_communication_failure = 1
      http_invalid_state         = 2
      http_processing_failed     = 3
      OTHERS                     = 5.
ENDIF.

call method lo_API02a->response->get_status
 IMPORTING
    code = lv_code
    REASON = reason.

response = lo_API02a->response->get_cdata( ).
CALL METHOD lo_API02a->close.
CALL METHOD lo_API02->close.
CALL METHOD LO_HTTP_CLIENT->close.

******End: run the job

WRITE: 'response: ', response.

 

 4. Finally you can check the result  via SAC-> Transport-> Monitor

 

Sources:

Introduction of SAC Multi-actions Public API - SAP Community

entry.title: SAP UI5 - Draft Handling in FreeStyle Applications
entry.content:
• 1. Creating a DraftManager Class
  • 1.1 Initialization
  • 1.2 Draft Functions in the DraftManager
  • 2. Instantiating the DraftManager in the Controller
  • 3. Using the DraftManager in the Controller
  • 3.1 Start Editing
  • 3.2 Save
  • 3.3 Cancel
  • 4. DraftHandling and MERGE lock errors
  • 5. Conclusion

 

1. Creating a DraftManager Class

In this post, I would like to share some of my experience with draft handling in FreeStyle applications.
After we decided in one of our projects to implement draft handling and at the same time had to consider our new component-based architecture, we encapsulated SAP‚Äôs DraftController (sap.ui.generic.app.transaction.DraftController) in a way that made sense for our use case.

I describe one possible encapsulation of the DraftController in a service class called "DraftManager", which (depending on the project) can be integrated and used across FreeStyle applications.
This approach worked very well for us, especially since official documentation was quite limited at that time.

Important: In our application we use an OData V2 service (with CDS views) that is already prepared accordingly for draft handling.

1.1 Initialization

The DraftManager is a service class used to encapsulate the DraftController.
The following basic structure has proven itself in our projects and can be used as is or adapted and extended as needed.

When initializing the DraftManager in the controller, we only pass the component instance and the view‚Äôs binding context.

(Example)

this.oDraftManager = new DraftManager(this.getOwnerComponent(), oContext);

The binding context is stored internally within the class for further processing and can be accessed or modified if required using the helper functions getActiveContext and setActiveContext.

Basic structure:

sap.ui.define([
  "sap/ui/generic/app/transaction/DraftController"
], function (DraftController) {
  "use strict";

  const DraftManager = function (oComponent, oContext) {
    this.oModel = oComponent.getModel();
    this.oDraftController = new DraftController(this.oModel);
    this.oActiveContext = oContext;
    this.oDraftContext = null;
  };

  DraftManager.prototype.setActiveContext = function (oContext) {
    this.oActiveContext = oContext;
  };

  DraftManager.prototype.getActiveContext = function () {
    return this.oActiveContext;
  };

  return DraftManager;
});

 

1.2 Draft Functions in the DraftManager

The DraftManager can be extended as needed, but in this post I would like to focus in particular on the main draft handling functions (Activate, Edit, and Discard).

Determine or Create a Draft

The DraftController itself is relatively easy to use.
However, there are operations, such as Edit, that always require multiple steps.
If a draft already exists, a new one cannot be created and an error will occur.

To avoid having to implement the same check in every controller, this logic is encapsulated.
This way, only a single function needs to be executed.

In this example code, we first check whether a draft exists for the active view context.
If so, it is returned and the controller can rebind the view accordingly.
If not, a new draft is created.

If needed, success and error messages can also be handled inside the function (for example, if they should be consistent across several applications). We use our own separate error handling in this case.

DraftManager.prototype.getOrCreateEditDraft = async function () {
  const oExistingDraft = await this.oDraftController.getDraftForActiveEntity(this.oActiveContext);

  if (oExistingDraft && !oExistingDraft.context.getObject().IsActiveEntity) {
    this.oDraftContext = oExistingDraft.context;
    return this.oDraftContext;
  }

  const oDraft = await this.oDraftController.createEditDraftEntity(this.oActiveContext);

  this.oDraftContext = oDraft.context;
  return this.oDraftContext;
};

Activate a Draft

Activating a draft is pretty straightforward in this case. Here as well: The function can be extended as needed (error + success handling e.g.)

DraftManager.prototype.activateDraft = async function () {
  await this.oDraftController.activateDraftEntity(this.oDraftContext);
  this.oActiveContext = this.oDraftContext;
};

Discard a Draft

Discarding a draft is also easy to implement in this case.

DraftManager.prototype.discardDraft = async function () {
  await this.oDraftController.discardDraft(this.oDraftContext);
  this.oDraftContext = null;
};

2. Instantiating the DraftManager in the Controller

As mentioned at the beginning, the DraftManager can be instantiated quite easily.

Example: We have a master/detail application with an onRouteMatched function in the detail controller.
Assume we have a SmartTable on the master page and navigate to the detail page after clicking on an entry.
Here, we pass the corresponding bound id (or guid) of the list item and the HasActiveEntity property.

Using this properties, we now create a raw context (helper function _loadContext) and start instantiating the DraftManager .

onRouteMatched: async function (oEvent) {
  const sId = oEvent.getParameter("arguments").UUID;
  const bActive = oEvent.getParameter("arguments").HasActiveEntity;

  try {
	const oContext = await this._loadContext("/EntitySet", { "UUID": sId, "IsActiveEntity": bActive });
	this.oDraftManager = new DraftManager(this.getOwnerComponent(), oContext);
  } catch (oError) {
	//error handling
  }  
}
_loadContext: async function (sEntity, oContextParameters) {
	const oModel = this.getView().getModel();
	await oModel.metadataLoaded();
	const sKey = oModel.createKey(sEntity, oContextParameters);
	const oContext = new sap.ui.model.Context(oModel, sKey);
	return Promise.resolve(oContext);
},

After that, the DraftManager is instantiated and can be used.

3. Using the DraftManager in the Controller

From this point on things become much more relaxed, as encapsulating the draft logic significantly reduces the number of operations in the controller.

I will keep the following examples to a minimum. Depending on the requirements, these can of course become more complex.

For rebinding/refreshing the view, we're using the following helper function:

_bindView: async function (sId, bIsActiveEntity) {
  return new Promise((resolve) => {
    this.getView().bindElement({
      path: `/EntitySet(UUID=guid'${sId}',IsActiveEntity=${bIsActiveEntity})`,
      parameters: {
        expand: "DraftAdministrativeData"
      },
      events: {
        change: (oEvent) => {
          resolve(oEvent.getSource().getBoundContext());
        }
      }
    });
  });
};

3.1 Start Editing

Editing has now become a fire-and-forget function, as everything is nicely encapsulated.
After each draft operation, the view should be updated (in this case using _bindView).

onEdit: async function () {
	try {	
		const oDraftContext = await this.oDraftManager.getOrCreateEditDraft();  
		await this._bindView(
			oDraftContext.getProperty("UUID"),
			oDraftContext.getProperty("IsActiveEntity")
		);		
	} catch (oError) {
		//error handling...
	}
}

3.2 Save

After activating the draft, the view is rebound to the active entity.

onSave: async function () {
	try {	
		await this.oDraftManager.activateDraft();  
		await this._bindView(
			this.oDraftManager.getActiveContext().getProperty("UUID"),
			this.oDraftManager.getActiveContext().getProperty("IsActiveEntity")
		);	
	} catch (oError) {
		//error handling...
	}
}

3.3 Cancel

When canceling, the draft is discarded and the view is rebound to the active context.

onDiscard: async function () {
	try {	
		await this.oDraftManager.discardDraft();
		await this._bindView(
			this.oDraftManager.getActiveContext().getProperty("UUID"),
			this.oDraftManager.getActiveContext().getProperty("IsActiveEntity")
		);
	} catch (oError) {
		//error handling...
	}
}

4. DraftHandling and MERGE lock errors

One important learning from our projects was dealing with MERGE lock errors.
As soon as draft handling is applied to larger views with many form fields and especially rich text editors, you will sooner or later run into locking issues, as we did.

This happens because the DraftController triggers a MERGE request on every change in the view (which is correct behavior).
However, if too many changes are performed too quickly, multiple MERGE requests can be sent at the same time and end up locking each other.

This can easily be reproduced with a rich text editor in the view by pressing the Enter key very quickly. The result is a large number of lock errors (The draft itself is still updated correctly, but this can become quite annoying when working with messaging).

Our solution for this was to work with deferredGroups and changeGroups.

In order to get this to work with the DraftController and the service class, we use the merge timer provided by SAP.

First we start by setting the deferredGroup and changeGroup in the onInit function of the view controller.

this.getOwnerComponent().getModel().setDeferredGroups(["Changes"]);
this.getOwnerComponent().getModel().setChangeGroups({
  "*": {
    groupId: "Changes",
    changeSetId: "Changes",
    single: false
  }
});
this.getOwnerComponent().getModel().attachPropertyChange(this.onEnqueueSubmitChanges.bind(this, 1));

After that we define the propertyChange handler function onEnqueueSubmitChanges.

onEnqueueSubmitChanges: function (nIntervalInSeconds) {
  const mParameters = this.getOwnerComponent().getModel("util").getProperty("/ViewControl/batchParameters");
  this.oDraftManager.triggerSubmitChanges(nIntervalInSeconds, mParameters);
}

And finally, we define a new DraftManager function triggerSubmitChanges, which bundles the requests using the merge timer and submits them accordingly.

oDraftManager.prototype.triggerSubmitChanges = function (nIntervalInSeconds, mParameters) {
  const oDraftMergeTimer = this.oDraftController._oDraftMergeTimer;
  if (!oDraftMergeTimer.nTimeoutID) {
    oDraftMergeTimer.nTimeoutID = setTimeout(() => {
      oDraftMergeTimer.nTimeoutID = null;
      if (this.oModel.hasPendingChanges()) {
        this.oDraftController.triggerSubmitChanges(mParameters)
          .catch((oError) => {
            console.error("Error during submit changes:", oError);
          });
      }
    }, (nIntervalInSeconds || 0) * 1000);
  }
};

5. Conclusion

I have reduced the examples to the basics, as they can be extended as needed. We had very good experience with this service class, and draft handling in FreeStyle applications in combination with an OData V2 service worked very well.

The DraftController can of course also be used directly in the controller.
However, as mentioned before, encapsulating it is worthwhile when working with a larger application architecture, especially when testing is relevant in the project.

entry.title: Why SAP S/4HANA Go‚ÄëLives Fail After ‚ÄúSuccess‚Äù: The Hidden Content & Attachment Layer
entry.content:
The Go‚ÄëLive That Lies

Many SAP S/4HANA programs proudly announce:
‚ÄúGo‚ÄëLive successful.‚Äù

But inside IT support teams, a different story starts:

  • Vendor PDFs missing from Purchase Orders

  • GOS icons showing empty

  • ArchiveLink documents failing to open

  • SOFFCONT1 exploding in HANA

  • SRGBTBREL links broken after BP conversion

  • SYSTEM_NO_ROLL dumps during data extraction

  • HANA memory growing with no business data added

None of this appears in standard cutover checklists.

Yet this is where most post‚Äëgo‚Äëlive instability originates.

Why This Happens

SAP migration tools (SUM, Migration Cockpit, SLO, DMO, etc.) are excellent at moving:

  • Business objects

  • Tables

  • Custom code

  • Transactions

They do not validate the content layer:

Layer What SAP Migrates What It Does NOT Validate
SOFFCONT1Raw binariesOrphaned blobs, duplicates, corruption
SRGBTBRELRelationship rowsWhether links still resolve
GOSUI iconsWhether documents open
ArchiveLinkMetadataRepository integrity
KProIDsFile existence

This means:

SAP migrates pointers ‚Äî not documents.

The result: a technically ‚Äúsuccessful‚Äù migration with business‚Äëcritical data silently broken.

Why ABAP Cannot Fix This at Scale

Most teams try to validate content using ABAP.

That fails because:

  • SOFFCONT1 and KPro use TBL1024 RAW data

  • Reading large binaries causes SYSTEM_NO_ROLL

  • ABAP has session memory limits

  • OData times out

  • Parallelization is weak

This is why:

2 TB of attachments can take weeks ‚Äî or never complete ‚Äî in ABAP.

What Actually Works

High‚Äëvolume SAP content must be validated outside SAP using:

  • RFC streaming (TBL1024 chunking)

  • External memory (Python, not ABAP)

  • Hash validation (SHA‚Äë256)

  • Parallel workers

This allows:

  • TB‚Äëscale extraction

  • Zero ABAP

  • No downtime

  • No production risk

This is how broken SRGBTBREL links, missing PDFs, and SOFFCONT1 bloat can be detected and repaired before they break finance, audits, and compliance.

Why CFOs Suddenly Care

When content explodes in S/4HANA:

  • Every GB = permanent HANA license cost

  • SOFFCONT1 often becomes top‚Äë5 table

  • 30‚Äì70% of content is usually dead, orphaned, or duplicated

This turns a technical cleanup into millions in avoided HANA spend.

That is why content engineering is now a CFO‚Äëgrade migration risk ‚Äî not a Basis detail.

The Missing Migration Gate

Every S/4 program should have a formal checkpoint:

‚ÄúIs our content layer safe, intact, and cost‚Äëoptimized?‚Äù

If not, the go‚Äëlive is incomplete.

Final Thought

S/4HANA migrations don‚Äôt fail in Finance, SD, or MM.
They fail in what those processes depend on:
Documents, PDFs, attachments, and legal records.

Those live in the layer nobody checks.

If you are running or planning an S/4HANA conversion and have never validated SOFFCONT1, SRGBTBREL, GOS, or ArchiveLink, you are running blind ‚Äî even if the system is green.

entry.title: Employee Central Global Benefits - Wallet Functionality
entry.content:
We are looking the EC Global Benefits module for a client and want to investigate the Wallet functionality in more detail.

The client has a requirement to have a Flex Credit/Bank setup for employees to purchase additional coverages for insurance and pension. This credit is calculated as a percentage of their annual salary and an additional requirement is to have remaining balances moved to the employees health spending account at the end of open enrolment.

We are trying to understand if the Wallet functionality can support this type of requirement in the Global Benefits module and to see if there's additional material on how to implement the wallet functionality.

entry.title: From Automation to Agentic Ops: MCP Servers in SAP Automation Pilot
entry.content:
Nowadays, Ops teams are under increasing pressure to act faster, automate more, and collaborate with AI-driven assistants, all of that without compromising control, security, or reliability. As landscapes grow more complex, the challenge is no longer whether to automate, but how to make automation easily consumable by teammates and AI agents alike.

With tasks-specific MCP servers in SAP Automation Pilot, SAP introduces a powerful way to expose operational capabilities in a structured, manageable, and agent-friendly manner.

Typical use cases include SAP BTP operations such as Cloud Foundry Apps and SAP HANA Cloud checks, validations, diagnostics and remediations; SAP cTMS scenarios like transport validation or execution; incident management, etc. Beyond these examples, MCP Servers remain fully flexible as they can be shaped around any operational context where repeatable, governed actions are needed. This allows teams to start with well-known SAP-specific automations and gradually expand into custom, landscape-specific scenarios, relevant to their own needs.

MCP (Model Context Protocol) servers allow selected automations and content from SAP Automation Pilot to be exposed as tools. Instead of developing MCP servers by writing code or learning complex libraries, we are using the low-code/no-code capabilities of Automation Pilot, to deliver AI agents based on the needs and expectations of our Ops teams.

Why This Matters for Ops Teams

Incident handling, health checks, remediation, or maintenance activities all require different sets of actions depending on the situation and real-time systems‚Äô state. Scenario-specific MCP servers reflect this reality by allowing Ops teams to group and expose only the automations relevant to a particular operational context. The result is an interaction model which is safe and secure for both humans and AI agents.

Because MCP servers are created using SAP Automation Pilot‚Äôs low-code / no-code capabilities, Ops teams can adapt quickly to new scenarios without writing custom APIs or services. Operational knowledge stays close to the teams who best understand their own use cases and IT resources and the agent is provided with precise tools proven to work instead of hard to assemble nuts & bolts.

From Automation to Agentic Operations

By exposing SAP Automation Pilot commands through MCP servers, operational actions become first-class capabilities that agents can consume dynamically.

This enables agentic interactions across many use cases, for example:

  • Agents can detect issues and trigger remediations;
  • DevOps and SRE teams can interact conversationally with agents;
  • Incident response becomes faster and more consistent;

Instead of navigating through multiple tools or help documents, the automations in agentic AI scenarios can be executed instantly, which dramatically reduces resolution time and manual effort.
At the same time, governance is built in. Only approved and selected automations are exposed, inputs are controlled, and every execution is auditable. This makes MCP servers suitable not just for experimentation, but for enterprise-scale production operations.

Once scenario-specific MCP servers are set up, they can be integrated seamlessly with various agent-based solutions, including also Cline and Joule (note: MCP server integration with Joule is already delivered, for more information, consult this blogpost: Agent builder in Joule Studio is now generally available: Build your own Joule agents today!).

This approach allows agents to move beyond recommendations and into real operational action without duplicating logic or skipping controls. Of course, SAP Automation Pilot remains the execution engine.

Learn More

If you would like to explore MCP servers in more detail or start using them in your own landscapes, please check out the SAP.Automation Pilot official documentation which provides further insights:

  • MCP Server Overview;
  • Managing MCP Servers;
  • Integrating SAP Automation Pilot with AI Agents;

Tasks-specific MCP servers mark an important step in the evolution from automated operations to AI agent-driven operations. If you have comments, ideas for scenarios, or topics you would like to explore further, feel free to leave a comment ‚Äî your feedback is very welcome.

entry.title: How to handle OR logic in SAP GRC rules for SuccessFactors when actions contain many fields
entry.content:
Hi Experts,

I am working on building GRC ruleset for SuccessFactors, and I am facing challenges related to rule design limitations.

In GRC, the rule framework does not support OR logic between fields or objects, this is standard functionality. However, this limitation becomes difficult to handle in SuccessFactors, where a single action (for example, Employee Central data) contains a very large number of fields.

Our requirement is to define rules where OR logic is needed between multiple fields within the same action (for example, access to any one of several EC data fields should trigger the rule). Without OR logic, this leads to an explosion of rules and makes maintenance complex and inefficient.

Has anyone faced a similar challenge while building GRC rules for SuccessFactors?

What approaches or best practices are recommended in such scenarios?

Are there any design patterns, workarounds, or SAP-recommended solutions to handle this effectively?
Any guidance or real-world experience would be greatly appreciated.

Thank you in advance for your support.

entry.title: Re: Third Party Sales of Service with attachment
entry.content:
Yes, this is doable in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, but not fully out of the box.

Approach (high level):

  • Use a third‚Äëparty sales / bill‚Äëthrough scenario where the supplier invoice amount is passed to customer billing (typically via service PO ‚Üí supplier invoice ‚Üí billing relevance).

  • For attaching the supplier invoice to the customer billing output:

    • Supplier invoice must be stored as an attachment (GOS / DMS / ArchiveLink).

    • Use Output Management (Adobe Form) to fetch and print or reference the attachment.

    • Automatic attachment transfer is not standard; it usually requires form logic or BTP-based extension.

In Public Cloud, limitations apply, so the recommended approach is Output Management extensibility or BTP side-by-side extension if the PDF must be embedded automatically.

entry.title: Re: SAP Version Compatibility for LOB Attachments in RAP
entry.content: Thanks @MioYasutake for the clarification. For S/4HANA 2021, native RAP LOB / stream handling is not fully supported (available from 2022 onwards), which explains the conditional If‚ÄëMatch error. The recommended workaround is a hybrid approach: use RAP for business data and handle attachments via classic SEGW OData, GOS, or ArchiveLink depending on the use case.

entry.title: Re: Unable to Rename the C4C Broadcast Attachments
entry.content:
In SAP C4C / Service Cloud, the file name and Excel sheet tab name of broadcast report attachments are system‚Äëgenerated and cannot be customized using standard functionality.

Key points:

  • Attachment name is generated internally (GUID-based)

  • Excel sheet tab name includes a timestamp by design

  • There is no configuration, PDI, or analytics setting to rename either of them

  • This applies to standard and custom reports

Possible workarounds:

  • Use the email subject/body to clearly mention the report name and period

  • Post-process the attachment externally (e.g. middleware, Power Automate, Outlook rule)

  • Download reports via UI/API and rename them outside C4C

  • Raise an SAP Influence / Feature Request if this is a business requirement

As of now, custom naming of broadcast attachments is not supported in C4C.

entry.title: Re: Focused Run: Early Watch Alert report as email attach...
entry.content:
In SAP Focused Run (5.1 and me.sap.com), sending the full EarlyWatch Alert (EWA) report as a PDF or HTML email attachment is not supported.

What is supported:

  • Email notifications for EWA availability

  • Emailing specific alerts/sections

  • Manual download of the full EWA report (DOCX from SAP for Me)

What is not supported (unlike Solution Manager):

  • Automatic emailing of the entire EWA report as PDF or HTML

  • Scheduling EWA as a complete email attachment to stakeholders

SAP has confirmed this limitation via:

  • Guided Answer 35654:40145

  • KBA 2930644 (EWA Troubleshooting Guide)

Workarounds:

  • Manually convert DOCX to PDF/HTML and distribute via email

  • Share EWA access links with stakeholders on SAP for Me

  • Use custom automation outside SAP (e.g. script or document workflow)

  • Submit an SAP Influence Request to request SolMan‚Äëlike functionality

As of now, there is no standard way to email the full EWA report as an attachment in Focused Run.

entry.title: AI in SAP SuccessFactors (2026) ‚Äî The Change Management Blueprint
entry.content:
AI in SAP SuccessFactors (2026) ‚Äî The Change Management Blueprint

Part 2 of the ‚ÄúPractical Implementation Blueprint‚Äù series

Quick continuity from Part 1: In Part 1 (the Practical Implementation Blueprint), we focused on the foundations that make AI possible in SuccessFactors - aligning use cases to personas, getting identity and permissions right, building readiness and governance, and planning the activation roadmap across Joule, embedded AI, and extensibility. We also set a clear principle: AI suggests; humans decide.

If you haven‚Äôt read Part 1 yet, start there first:
üëâPart 1 ‚Äî AI in SAP SuccessFactors (2026): The Practical Implementation Blueprint

Now Part 2 goes where most programs struggle: change management - including how to enable frontline managers to confidently handle human-in-the-loop responsibilities (reviewing AI output, validating key facts, and owning final decisions). In 2026, AI in HR has moved beyond pilots; organizations are wiring AI into everyday SuccessFactors workflows through Joule and embedded capabilities. The teams that win won‚Äôt be the ones that merely ‚Äúturn on‚Äù AI - they‚Äôll be the ones that treat adoption as a product: clear outcomes, clear boundaries, and a manager-led reinforcement model.

What you‚Äôll get in this blog

  • A practical plan to secure leadership buy-in (not just approval)
  • A manager-first adoption model (frontline managers are the adoption engine)
  • A pre-launch checklist to prepare employees before AI goes live
  • A communications cadence (pre-launch ‚Üí launch ‚Üí sustain)
  • An enablement model that makes AI a habit (micro-learning + in-app guidance + champions)
  • Ready-to-use templates: Trust Charter, manager talk track (with a HITL checklist), myth-vs-fact, 30-60-90 plan

0) A quick reality check: what changed in 2026

AI in SuccessFactors typically shows up in three layers:

  • Digital assistant experience (Joule): a ‚Äúfront door‚Äù to ask, navigate, and get guided support across workflows. Users need permission to access it (for example, ‚ÄúAccess to Joule‚Äù in RBP).
  • Embedded AI in modules: AI-assisted experiences inside Recruiting, Learning, Performance, and other areas (depending on scope/entitlements).
  • Extensibility (Joule Studio): the layer (via SAP Build) to create and manage custom Joule agents/skills for your organization, including SAP and non-SAP workflows.

This blog is not about ‚Äúturning it on.‚Äù It is about making AI stick through trust, enablement, and manager-led reinforcement.

1) Make adoption a workstream (not a side activity)

If adoption is treated as ‚Äúa few emails and a training session,‚Äù usage will spike for 2‚Äì3 weeks and then fade. Treat adoption like a delivery stream with owners, deliverables, and success metrics.

Minimum adoption workstreams you need

  • Leadership sponsorship (cadence + outcome ownership)
  • Manager enablement (talk tracks + coaching + resistance handling)
  • Employee readiness (trust + safe use cases + support model)
  • Enablement (micro-learning + in-app guidance + champions)
  • Measurement (adoption + trust + value + safety signals)

Non-negotiable: If your first serious communication about AI happens after employees see it in the system, you are already late. Start manager readiness and trust messaging before launch.

2) Define outcomes + ‚Äúsafe scope‚Äù before you communicate

Communications and training fail when people don‚Äôt know: (1) what AI is for, (2) what it is not for, (3) what is safe to use, and (4) who remains accountable.

2.1 Outcome model (simple but measurable)

  • Experience: faster HR ‚Äúhow do I‚Äù answers, fewer failed attempts, higher completion rates
  • Operational: reduced HR tickets, reduced cycle time for common tasks, fewer errors
  • Manager: improved coaching consistency, faster drafting of goals/feedback (with human review)

2.2 ‚ÄúSafe scope‚Äù statement (trust accelerator)

  • Safe examples: navigation, policy/process Q&A, drafting text that users review and edit, learning guidance, skills exploration
  • Not in scope: sensitive decisions where humans must decide (for example, pay/promo/termination)
  • Accountability line: ‚ÄúAI suggests; humans decide.‚Äù

2.3 EU AI Act lens: assistive vs high-risk (EU programs)

For EU entities, map each AI use case to the EU AI Act‚Äôs risk logic. Many common uses are assistive (surfacing information, drafting content, guiding navigation) when designed for meaningful human review. However, AI used for recruitment, promotion, termination, or worker management decisions may fall into the ‚Äúemployment, workers‚Äô management and access to self-employment‚Äù high-risk category (Annex III).

  • For every AI use case, document whether it is assistive/preparatory or potentially high-risk.
  • Where you conclude a use case is not high-risk, record the rationale and controls before scaling (human-in-the-loop checks, no automated decisions, limited impact).

3) Leadership buy-in: from ‚Äúapproval‚Äù to ‚Äúownership‚Äù

Your sponsor must do more than endorse - they must actively reinforce the new behaviors, remove blockers, and keep the program outcome-driven.

3.1 Sponsor responsibilities (keep them explicit)

  • Own outcomes: commit to 3‚Äì5 measurable outcomes (Section 2)
  • Be visible: repeated reinforcement, not a one-time kickoff message
  • Build coalition: HR + IT + Security/Privacy (+ Works Council where applicable)
  • Remove blockers: fix friction quickly (permissions, confusing outputs, gaps in help content)

3.2 Sponsor toolkit (minimum viable set)                                                                                                       

AssetPurposeWhen used
AI Vision (1 page)Why now + what outcomes we expectPre-launch
AI Guardrails (1 page)Trust boundaries + accountabilityPre-launch + launch
Sponsor cadence planMake sponsorship visible and repeatable0‚Äì90 days
Adoption dashboardSteer with evidenceMonthly

4) Frontline managers: the adoption engine (most often overlooked)

Frontline managers decide whether AI becomes ‚Äúhow we work‚Äù or ‚Äúanother feature we ignore.‚Äù Use this manager model as your operating rhythm: Communicate ‚Üí Model ‚Üí Assign ‚Üí Coach ‚Üí Reinforce.

4.1 Manager success pattern (use this as your operating rhythm)

  • Communicate the ‚Äúwhy‚Äù and the ‚Äúguardrails‚Äù
  • Model using Joule in a team setting (for example, find a policy, confirm a process)
  • Assign two starter tasks (simple, safe, high value)
  • Coach quality: ‚ÄúWhat was helpful? What wasn‚Äôt? What should we avoid?‚Äù
  • Reinforce weekly for the first month

4.2 Manager enablement kit (plug-and-play)

  • 2-minute talk track (included in Templates)
  • 5 starter tasks (examples below)
  • Myth vs Fact sheet (included in Templates)
  • Escalation path (who to contact for permissions/content/incorrect answers)
  • Coaching guide (how to reinforce habits without adding workload)

4.2A Human-in-the-loop for managers: what ‚Äúgood‚Äù looks like

In Part 1, we called out that ‚ÄúAI suggests; humans decide.‚Äù In practice, this becomes a repeatable manager habit only when you make it explicit and easy. The goal is not to slow managers down - it is to ensure AI is used safely, consistently, and with clear accountability.

Manager responsibilityWhat to do (simple rule)    When to escalate
Review AI outputScan for tone, relevance, and missing context before sharing or approving.If output is inappropriate, biased, or unsafe.
Validate key factsFor policy/process answers: verify against the official source link before acting.If the answer conflicts with policy or local legal guidance.
Own the final decisionUse AI as input; document your reasoning when decisions impact people (hiring, promotion, termination, pay).If the use case resembles automated decisioning or creates legal/compliance risk.
Use ‚Äúminimum necessary‚Äù dataDon‚Äôt paste sensitive personal data into prompts; keep prompts task-focused.If users request AI to analyze highly sensitive cases.
Give feedbackReport wrong/confusing outputs so the COE can improve content, guardrails, and guidance.If issues repeat or appear systematic.

Manager shortcut: If an AI output could influence a people decision, apply this habit: Verify ‚Üí Apply judgment ‚Üí Decide ‚Üí Document.

4.3 Five starter tasks (managers can run in 10 minutes)

  • Ask Joule where to find [policy/process] and share the correct link with the team
  • Draft your next 1:1 agenda using AI writing support, then edit it yourself
  • Draft a goal statement (you own the final version)
  • Ask ‚ÄúHow do I complete [common manager task]?‚Äù and validate the steps
  • Share one myth you heard and validate it using the Trust Charter

5) Prepare employees before launch (trust + clarity + support)

Employees will adopt AI only if they trust boundaries and understand what is safe. Before launch, explicitly answer: What can I use it for? What should I not use it for? What data can it access? Who is accountable?

Pre-launch employee readiness checklist

  • Plain-language Trust Charter (included below)
  • Approved use-case menu (6‚Äì10 safe, high-value examples)
  • Feedback loop: how employees report wrong/confusing output
  • Support model: office hours + champions + escalation rules

6) Communications plan (pre-launch ‚Üí launch ‚Üí sustain)

Communication is not ‚Äúone email.‚Äù It is a rhythm: trust + clarity + reinforcement, avoiding both hype and silence about guardrails.

Phase
TimingAudienceMessage focusChannels
Pre-launchT-4 to T-1 weeksLeaders + ManagersWhy, outcomes, guardrails, manager roleEmail, leadership briefing, manager call
LaunchWeek 0Pilot cohortStart-here tasks + support + feedback loopIn-app banner, Teams/Slack, short demo
StabilizeWeeks 1‚Äì4Pilot + managersConfidence building, myth-busting, early winsOffice hours, tips, manager nudges
ScaleWeeks 5‚Äì12Next cohortsProof (metrics), champions, reinforcementTownhall mention, FAQ refresh, in-app guidance

7) Enablement model: verified AI literacy + in-workflow support

AI adoption rarely scales through classroom training alone; people need micro-learning, in-workflow guidance, performance support, and champions.

7.1 Verified AI literacy (especially important in EU programs)

Build AI literacy into your plan from Day 0. For EU programs, treat AI literacy as a formal enablement item - not an afterthought.

7.2 Enablement components (recommended minimum)

  • Employees: 10‚Äì15 minutes micro-learning + safe use cases + Trust Charter
  • Managers: talk track + starter tasks + coaching guide
  • HR/COE: governance, content quality loop, escalation handling
  • In-app guidance: task walkthroughs for complex processes
  • Office hours: weekly for first month

7.3 Tooling that supports adoption

  • SAP Enable Now: enablement content to drive adoption and productivity
  • Digital adoption platforms: on-screen walkthroughs, nudges, and analytics to see where processes stall
  • Joule: ‚Äúhelp in the moment‚Äù for navigational and how-to support (when properly governed)

30-60-90 rollout plan with gates (don‚Äôt scale without them)

Day 0‚Äì30: Trust + habit formation (pilot)

  • Launch to a controlled cohort (example: 100‚Äì500 users)
  • Weekly office hours + track top 10 questions
  • Publish ‚ÄúTop 10 safe use cases‚Äù and refine weekly
  • Manager nudges: 2 starter tasks/week + 7-day check-in

Day 31‚Äì60: Stabilize + expand

  • Expand only when gates are met (below)
  • Introduce additional use cases based on value + safety
  • Strengthen in-app guidance where drop-offs occur

Day 61‚Äì90: Scale + operationalize

  • Move to COE rhythm: monthly adoption review + governance
  • Quarterly enablement refresh (new use cases + refreshed trust messaging)
  • Shift from ‚Äúproject‚Äù to ‚Äúproduct‚Äù operating model

Adoption gates (example)

  • Trust signal: fewer ‚Äúis this safe?‚Äù questions + sentiment improving
  • Repeat usage: repeat users increasing week-over-week
  • Manager engagement: managers completing starter tasks + coaching teams
  • Escalation health: issues logged + resolution time improving

9) Measure adoption beyond ‚Äúusage‚Äù

Usage alone is not success. Track adoption, trust, value, and safety together.

9.1 Suggested AI adoption KPI set (pilot-ready)

 

DimensionMetricDescriptionPilot target example
AdoptionActive Joule users (7/30 days)Unique users issuing AI queries in a given window40‚Äì60% of pilot
AdoptionRepeat usersUsers active in at least 3 weeks out of 4Upward trend weekly
ValueTicket deflectionReduction in HR support tickets for ‚Äúhow do I‚Äù topics10‚Äì25% reduction
ValueTime-to-completeMedian completion time for 3‚Äì5 frequent transactions20‚Äì40% reduction
TrustConfidence / sentiment scorePulse: ‚ÄúI understand what is safe and I trust boundaries‚Äù>75% favorable
SafetyPermission boundary incidentsEscalations about access/scope issuesFlat or decreasing
ComplianceEU risk assessment coverageAI use cases assessed and documented (assistive vs high-risk)100% of relevant

10) Templates (copy/paste)

10.1 The AI Trust Charter (employee-facing)

The AI Trust Charter

  • Data privacy: we apply enterprise controls to protect confidential information.
  • Security: AI can only access connected data sources within your authorizations/permissions.
  • Accountability: AI is a tool, not a decision-maker. Humans remain accountable for sensitive decisions.
  • Transparency + feedback: we communicate where AI is used and how to report outputs that are unclear or incorrect.

10.2 Myth vs Fact (employee comms)

MythFact
‚ÄúAI can see my private chats.‚ÄùFalse. AI access depends on connected systems and your permissions/authorizations.
‚ÄúAI will decide who gets promoted.‚ÄùFalse. AI may support insights, but humans remain accountable for decisions.
‚ÄúIf AI suggests it, it must be correct.‚ÄùFalse. AI outputs require human judgment and validation; use the feedback loop to report issues.
‚ÄúIf I don‚Äôt use AI, I‚Äôll be left behind.‚ÄùPartly true. AI literacy is becoming a core workplace skill - which is why enablement and safe use cases are provided.

10.3 Manager talk track (2 minutes) + HITL checklist

1) Why we‚Äôre doing this:
We‚Äôre introducing AI support in SuccessFactors to simplify HR work and free time for coaching and value-added work.

2) What it is (and isn‚Äôt):
It helps with guidance and productivity. It does not replace human decisions in sensitive areas.

3) What I need you to do:
Try the two starter tasks this week and share what worked / what didn‚Äôt. If something looks wrong, use the feedback channel.

4) The HITL checklist (use this when AI output touches people decisions):
- Verify key facts (policy/process)
- Apply judgment (context + fairness)
- Decide (you own the outcome)
- Document (why the decision was made)

5) Where to get help:
Use office hours, our champions, and in-app help. Escalate issues quickly ‚Äî we will fix them.

10.4 Sponsor 30-60-90 template

Sponsor Outcome: ________________________________
Success Metrics (3-5): ___________________________

Day 0-30:
- Visible sponsorship moment(s): _________________
- Barriers removed: ______________________________
- Reinforcement message delivered: ________________

Day 31-60:
- Cohort expansion decision (go/no-go): ___________
- Adoption review (trust + usage + issues): ________
- Recognition plan: _______________________________

Day 61-90:
- Move to COE/product operating model: ____________
- Quarterly enablement refresh: ___________________

Final note: treat AI as a product, not a project

The goal isn‚Äôt go-live; the goal is habit, trust, and measurable value. The organizations that win in 2026 will treat AI in SAP SuccessFactors as a product: continuously improving approved use cases, strengthening enablement, reinforcing manager behaviors, and measuring outcomes.

Coming next (Part 3): A practical AI Adoption Operating Model - COE structure, cadence, backlog, governance, and release-alignment.

entry.title: Re: Introducing the new pipeline concept in Cloud Integration

entry.title: Re: the CDS of APP Display Actual Costing Result
entry.content:
Are you asking about the CDS view behind the app?

if thats the query then its I_ActualCostingRunResult

This is a Query category CDS view that aggregates data for the actual costing results. It is built upon several foundational system tables and views to provide a comprehensive look at the costing run outcomes. This can be used for reporting purpose.

Depending on exactly which data you are trying to extract from the "Actual Costing" logic, you may also find these related CDS views useful:

I_ActlCostgMatlValueChainItem is a fact view Used for the Material Value Chain display (visualizing the flow of costs).

I_ActualCostingActivityResult is a fact view which focuses on the activity data (cost centers/activities) within the actual costing run.

I_ML_BALANCE Is a consumption view 

Often used to check actual costs for materials in a balance summary format.

hope this helps.

Best Regards,

Bidisha

entry.title: Re: How to fix message No.SFIN_FI016 in S/4 HANA
entry.content:
This is the security issue not FICO configuration issue. Here are the steps to fix it.

Step 1:

use SU53  to find the authorizations we lacked

Step 2: use SUIM to find the roles we lacked

1) execute below menu

2) input selection according to findings in step 1

3) execute the selection, get the roles we lacked

Step 3:

use SU01 to assign these roles to the corresponding accounts

entry.title: JSON Payload Download Implementation in RAP Application
entry.content:
Hello Expert,

I am currently working on a custom RAP (RESTful ABAP Programming Model) Application in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud. In this application, we use an API to send data to an external portal.

Now there is a new requirement when the user clicks a button, the JSON payload that is used in the ABAP program for sending data via the API should be downloaded in JSON format.

For this purpose, I have already created a custom action in the Behavior Definition, and the button is visible in the Application. My question is how to implement the download functionality so that the same JSON payload used for the API call can be downloaded by the user in JSON format and Also, please explain how to implement the JSON download functionality in the RAP application with step by step guidance.

Thank you,
